Interaction Materials and Controllers¶

An Interaction Behaviour component uses an Interaction Material object to define its settings and behaviour. Every Interaction Behaviour must have an interaction material to function properly. The Interaction Engine module provides a default material usable in most situations, but you can add more materials to define different behaviors for different types of interactable objects in your project.

To create a new Interaction Material, you can either use the Unity menu command: Assets>Create>Interaction Material, or right-click in the project window and select Create>Interaction Material.

An Interaction Material has a number of different controller objects that control various aspects of an Interaction Behaviour. These controllers can be specified by the material that an Interaction Behaviour is using, or can be manually overridden by the user. There are 5 different types of controllers:

HoldingPoseController¶

A HoldingPoseController controller is required and must be specified for every InteractionMaterial.

This controller controls what the transform of a held object should be. Different controllers can be used to have an object be held in different ways. For example you might create a handle pose controller to cause an object always be held in a certain orientation.

Currently the only built-in pose controller is the HoldingPoseControllerKabsch, which is a general purpose solver that tries to find a reasonable pose for general cases. This pose controller works best with cubical and spherical objects 1-2 inches in size.

MoveToController¶

A MoveToController controller is required and must be specified for every InteractionMaterial.

Once a held pose is determined, the MoveToController controls how the object should arrive at that location and orientation. Currently there are two built-in move-to controllers: Kinematic and Velocity. The kinematic controller simply uses kinematic position changes to move the object to its destination. The velocity controller sets the velocity of the object such that it is pushed to its destination, which can appear a lot more realistic and natural.

SuspensionController¶

A SuspensionController is optional. If not specified, no action is taken when an object is suspended.

The suspension controller decides what should happen to an object when the hand holding it moves out of the Leap Motion device’s field of view or is otherwise lost. Currently the very simple, default implementation disables the object’s renderers and makes it freeze in space. It places the object back in the hand and turns on the object’s renderers when the hand becomes tracked again. If the timeout period elapses first, the object is restored where it was located when the hand was lost.

ThrowingController¶

A ThrowingController is optional. If not specified, the Interaction Engine takes no action when you throw an object A thrown object will simply move with the velocity it had upon release.

The throwing controller decides what should happen when an object is released. More specifically, in what ways it should move. There are two built-in controllers, the PalmVelocity controller, and the SlidingWindow controller. The PalmVelocity controller uses the velocity of the palm to decide how the object should move, to prevent the fingers from imparting strange and incorrect velocities to the object. The SlidingWindow controller takes the average velocity of the palm over a customizable window before the release occurred.

LayerController¶

A LayerController is optional. If not specified, the layers provided by the interaction manager are used.

The LayerController simply decides what layers the interaction behaviour should be in for both it’s default state, and it’s state when it is ignoring brushes. The only built-in controller is a controller that allows you to provide overrides for the defaults, but no other functionality.

Creating your own controllers¶

To create your own controller, simply create a class that implements the abstract class for that controller. Once your class is created, it will automatically show up in the dropdown for that controller in the material interface. You can have serialized variables in your controller just like you would for a MonoBehaviour as well, which are automatically shown in the material inspector when that controller is chosen.
